confession.devil_appearance: dressed in black and like a soldier
confession.seduction_context: An unknown man dressed in black and like a soldier came into a room of her house at Sachemont when her husband was away, seized her, and had intercourse with her. He had not spoken to her and left immediately. Initially described as rape, then said he promised money so she gave in more easily, but he had been a normal man like her husband. Later identified him as Vincent du Foire of Bar-le-duc, whose wife had told her he ran after other women and kept two or three. He was said on the village to be 'le thaurel ou voirel de la ville'.

testimony.quarrel_subject: refused to give milk; she complained that they gave to others
testimony.threat_quote: commenca a dire qu'on luy refusoit du laict, qu'on en bailloit bien a d'autres, et qu'on s'en pourroit bien repentir

witnesses.name: Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault, de Sachemont

testimony.quarrel_subject: he made reference to incident where accused allegedly went to sabbat by the 'cramet' (cauldron) without naming her
testimony.threat_quote: qu'on faisoit quelque fois bien grand tort aux personnes

testimony.quarrel_subject: asked for something from his cow, servants refused without master's permission; she was discontented

witnesses.name: Claudatte femme de Colas Claudon Grainel

testimony.quarrel_subject: after son's burial dinner, Epnon begged and was dissatisfied with plate of millet

witnesses.name: Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie de Sachemont

testimony.quarrel_subject: Epnon came while witness was out, her mother was baking and Epnon did some baking herself; servants said she passed and repassed in front of animals and bull became ill
testimony.threat_quote: que suivant le mauvais bruit qu'elle portoit elle l'en soubconnoit, que sy touttesfois elle estoit femme de bien comme elle disoit qu'elle la laissoit pour telle aussy

witnesses.name: Claudon Colas le viel homme, de Sachemont

testimony.quarrel_subject: after wife gave birth, held feast for women; Epnon invited as neighbor but may have felt neglected or discontented they gave her nothing to take to her sick husband

witnesses.name: Catherine veuve de Fleurant Hagimont, de Sachemont

testimony.quarrel_subject: when they were neighbors, both raising goat kids; Epnon remarked that witness's goats were better than hers
bought half of her house and started getting violent headaches while moving in; also shared out garden but Epnon discontented, complained to others he didn't do it fairly

witnesses.name: Mengeon Chandel de La Hault, de Sachemont

testimony.quarrel_subject: after mother's death, she asked if there were any clothes she could have; he replied he had no right to give them to strangers, sisters had more claim
testimony.threat_quote: s'il ne vouloit poinct donner qu'il le laisse, et qu'elle luy pourroit coster trois fois plus que ce qu'il luy donneroit pourroit valloir

witnesses.name: Bastien Jean Chesne de Sachemont
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: son-in-law (married wife's father, so they lived together)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Around St. Jean 2 years before, during thunderstorm at night, heard a voice calling her to go out; she got out of bed, when asked next day gave unconvincing explanation about taking milk off fire

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Taken by Prévôt of Saint Dié, at request of PG de Lorraine's substitut

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: First interrogation; she gave biographical details, said she was about 60, poor widow who did day labour or begged to support herself, owned only part of house, could hardly see

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Interrogation and confrontations; no result; Epnon continued sensible denials of crucial points while agreeing to circumstantial details - unusually consistent case

timeline.subject: Mengel Forbain
timeline.details: Additional witness testimony; claimed 3 years earlier Epnon gave dried cherries to his daughter-in-law Mongeatte after childbirth, she immediately became ill and remained 'chaitte ou etique', unable to work

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Procureur general of Lorraine (C.M. Remy) asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Approved same day by Change de Nancy

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture in July; pointed out numerous witnesses, recently accused by woman of Tantrux who maintained accusation to execution. Given thumbscrews then racked; noted she endured much pain but was resolute. Denied any pact or malefice.

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Said she had been thinking of man who raped her and thought it had been Vincent du Foire of Bar-le-duc, whose wife told her he ran after other women and kept two or three; said on village to be 'le thaurel ou voirel de la ville'

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Procureur general asks for further torture, but Change de Nancy rules that she should be renvoyée jusqu'à rappel, unless he produces further evidence against her

timeline.subject: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
timeline.details: Released with warning about future conduct

prior_accusations.context: Epnon had recently been accused by a woman of Tantrux, had been taken to confrontation with her, and the woman maintained accusation up to her execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
notable_quotes.french: commenca a dire qu'on luy refusoit du laict, qu'on en bailloit bien a d'autres, et qu'on s'en pourroit bien repentir
notable_quotes.english: began to say that they refused her milk, that they gave it to others, and that they could well repent of it
notable_quotes.context: Threat after being refused milk at Bastien Colas George's house

notable_quotes.speaker: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
notable_quotes.french: qu'on faisoit quelque fois bien grand tort aux personnes
notable_quotes.english: that people sometimes do great wrong to persons
notable_quotes.context: Response when Michiel made reference to sabbat incident; she seemed to cry

notable_quotes.speaker: Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie
notable_quotes.french: que suivant le mauvais bruit qu'elle portoit elle l'en soubconnoit, que sy touttesfois elle estoit femme de bien comme elle disoit qu'elle la laissoit pour telle aussy
notable_quotes.english: that following the bad reputation she had, she suspected her of it, but if she was a good woman as she said, she would leave her as such
notable_quotes.context: Warning to Epnon about sick bull

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Chandel de La Hault
notable_quotes.french: s'il ne vouloit poinct donner qu'il le laisse, et qu'elle luy pourroit coster trois fois plus que ce qu'il luy donneroit pourroit valloir
notable_quotes.english: if he didn't want to give, let him leave it, and it could cost him three times more than what he would give could be worth
notable_quotes.context: Threat after witness refused to give her his dead mother's clothes

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastien Jean Chesne (son-in-law)
notable_quotes.french: autrement sy elle l'enduroit, qu'on l'apprehendroit quelques jours, et luy feroit on son proces, laquelle sur ce luy replicquoit qu'elle estoit seulle, et n'avoit aulcune deffence ny adsistance pour ce faire
notable_quotes.english: otherwise if she endured it, one day they would apprehend her and put her on trial, to which she replied that she was alone and had no defense or assistance to do so
notable_quotes.context: Warning to Epnon about being called witch and her response about inability to seek redress

notable_quotes.speaker: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
notable_quotes.french: et que ce sont fortunes qui arrivent, comme il plaist a dieu
notable_quotes.english: and these are misfortunes that happen, as it pleases God
notable_quotes.context: Her defense about animal deaths during interrogation

notable_quotes.speaker: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
notable_quotes.context: Her explanation for why she had a reputation as a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Epnon veuve Jean Charbonatte
notable_quotes.french: il eut ung remord de conscience, et pensa en luy mesme que c'estoit mal faict d'aller ainsy au devin, que comme il soupconnait ladite prevenue dudit mal, ad cause du bruict qu'elle portoit d'estre sorciere, s'en ayant descouvert a elle et a sondit marit, peult estre elle luy pourroit apporter quelque remede
notable_quotes.english: he had a remorse of conscience, and thought in himself that it was wrong to go thus to the diviner, that as he suspected the said accused of said illness, because of the reputation she had of being a witch, having disclosed it to her and her said husband, perhaps she could bring him some remedy
notable_quotes.context: Jean Masson's account of his journey to Remiremont and decision to turn back, reflecting on seeking cure from Epnon herself

relationships.evidence_text: Last husband had been Jean Chesne alias Charbonnatte, who had died three years earlier; he had been carpenter, mason, cooper and charcoal burner
First husband had been Mongeon Mathieu of Tantrux, who had died after only 6 weeks of marriage; died of 'rouge nal' after being sick 4 days
Second husband Claudon Mengel of Sachemont, who died after a year; had been ill 8 days after being struck on head with pewter pot by Auparlier of Avould
Daughter of Colas Martin of Chanry in Ban de Tantrux
Had two children by Jean Chesne, one of whom was alive, being about 18 and keeping horses towards Val de Moustier in Allemagne
Had a daughter by second husband, but she was 'innocente', and she had died a few years later - it had been a 'belle grace' of God to take her, in view of her infirmity
She had married his wife's father, so that they now lived together
Both of Sachemont; she came to his house and asked servants for milk; he had given her alms as a good man

relationships.person1: Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault
relationships.evidence_text: Both of Sachemont; she came up to him in street

relationships.person1: Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault
relationships.evidence_text: Daughter-in-law of the accused had come to their house to report incident
She came to his house; he often did make gifts when she came to house

relationships.person1: Claudatte femme de Colas Claudon Grainel
relationships.evidence_text: Epnon had been resident more than 30 years in Sachemont
Epnon was invited as neighbour to feast after wife gave birth
When they were neighbours, both raising goat kids
Had bought half of her house and moved in; shared out garden
Claudatte femme de Colas Claudon Grainel
Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie de Sachemont
Catherine veuve de Fleurant Hagimont
his daughter-in-law Mongeatte
Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault

economic_context.details: Epnon was described as very poor, owning only part of her house, could hardly see, so that she now had to beg rather than work. She did day labour or begged to support herself. There was a dispute over garden sharing with Jean Masson. She was owed 100 francs compensation from a previous legal case (200 francs were supposed to go to children of previous marriage) but never received it. Multiple witnesses described her coming to beg for food, milk, clothes. Her third husband had been ill for three years, emaciated and bedridden before death.

harms_catalog.harm_description: bull worth 50 francs, which had been well previous night, was found in morning lying down so that 6 men could not raise it; seemed to recover after eating bread and salt from Epnon's house, then became sick again a few hours later and finally died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: asked servants for milk and come and gone among animals; when refused, complained that they gave to others and they could repent of it
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft; partially cured by bread and salt from her house (counter-magic)

harms_catalog.victim_name: Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault
harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill with swollen neck and throat; when not improved after a week and could find no cure, remembered words he had said to Epnon and her long and great reputation; went to seek something from her house; began to recover immediately after eating yeast, salt and 'joutte' given by her daughter-in-law
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: he made reference to incident about her going to sabbat by the 'cramet' without naming her; she seemed to cry and said people did great wrong
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft; cured by eating items from her house (counter-magic)

harms_catalog.harm_description: pig worth 6 francs sickened, dying within a week
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: she came to ask for something from his cow, servants told her they could not give it without master's permission; she was discontented

harms_catalog.harm_description: foal worth 8 ecus sickened and died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: had asked his daughter to make some toile for her, only to be told that she didn't have time at present

harms_catalog.victim_name: Claudatte femme de Colas Claudon Grainel
harms_catalog.harm_description: terrible pains in face, with mouth twisted almost backwards - still not completely cured; had been told by neighbours that some 'egiptiens' who had been in village declared it was witchcraft
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: after son's burial dinner, Epnon came to beg; dissatisfied with plate of millet she was given (and ate), witness told her everything else had been eaten and she went away without showing resentment

harms_catalog.victim_name: bull of Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie
harms_catalog.harm_description: bull became ill after Epnon passed and repassed in front of animals; witness sent message through son-in-law that if Epnon did not take sickness off the animal, she would have her arrested; next day Epnon came to say she was a good woman and distressed to be blamed; same day the bull began to recover
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Epnon came while witness was out, her mother was baking and Epnon did some baking herself; servants said she had passed and repassed in front of animals
harms_catalog.method_alleged: passing and repassing in front of animals; cured when Epnon came to deny causing it

harms_catalog.victim_name: wife of Claudon Colas le viel homme
harms_catalog.harm_description: after giving birth, wife became unwell and lost her milk; midwife recommended they seek remedy from a woman of Souche; cunning woman gave him bread and something else, said wife should eat a little for nine days; also said if they suspected someone and she came to house before dinner offering something to eat, wife should accept and eat it because it would help her; same day Epnon appeared with cherries for his wife; when she ate them her appetite returned and she made a quick recovery
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: held customary feast for women after wife gave birth, Epnon invited as neighbour; didn't know if she had felt neglected, had also heard she was discontented because they gave her nothing to take to her sick husband
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft; cured by eating cherries from Epnon (counter-magic advised by cunning woman)

harms_catalog.victim_name: 5 goat kids of Catherine veuve de Fleurant Hagimont
harms_catalog.harm_description: they went blind, their eyes literally dropping out, and she had to sell them as best she could
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: when they were neighbours, she was raising 5 goat kids; Epnon also had some, and one day when they were all together she remarked that those of the witness were better than hers

harms_catalog.harm_description: while moving in, started to get violent headaches; returned at 3-day intervals for some 11 weeks, after which he had seemed cured, only to have relapse when working in Allemagne; returned home and told Epnon and her husband of his affliction, saying he had been told of someone in Burgundy who would identify the person who caused it; went to do so and got as far as Remiremont where he had remorse of conscience and thought it was wrong to go to diviner, that since he suspected Epnon perhaps she could bring him some remedy; did in fact recover on return home
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: bought half of her house and was moving in
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft; recovered after telling her and threatening to visit diviner

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: had shared out garden; Epnon's husband was too ill to participate, so he did it himself in her presence, but she was apparently discontented and complained to others that he hadn't done it fairly

harms_catalog.harm_description: goat which had been giving abundant milk started to lose this, so that he sold it
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: his wife had been giving Epnon milk from the animal, but perhaps not enough

after his mother's death, she came to ask if there were any of her clothes she could have; he replied that he had no right to give them to anyone but his sisters, who had far more claim to them than any stranger did; she then threatened it could cost him three times more than what he would give could be worth

harms_catalog.harm_description: had lost another bull some 6 weeks earlier, after which he had threatened her with having her taken to St. Dié and tried as a witch; since then she had not visited his house as she ordinarily did
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: after this death he threatened her with trial
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 6 weeks before the other bull death

harms_catalog.harm_description: some 3 years earlier, after childbirth, the accused had given some dried cherries to his daughter-in-law Mongeatte; she had immediately become ill, and had since remained 'chaitte ou etique' (wasted/consumptive), unable to work

material_culture.context: Epnon asked servants for milk at Bastien Colas George's house; refused. Jean Masson's wife had been giving Epnon milk from their goat, but perhaps not enough
Bastien Colas George sought bread and salt from Epnon's house to cure his bull after taking advice; she gave him this and bull seemed to recover on eating it
Daughter-in-law reported that Epnon got up during night when thundering to do something with a cauldron under bed; next day her husband accused his mother of having been to sabbat by the 'cramet'
Given by Epnon's daughter-in-law to Michiel when Epnon left hurriedly; he ate them and immediately began to recover from illness
Plate of millet given to Epnon after burial dinner; she was dissatisfied with it
Epnon asked Claudon Grinel's daughter to make some toile for her; told she didn't have time
Epnon brought cherries to wife of Claudon Colas; when she ate them her appetite returned and she made quick recovery; also dried cherries given to Mongeatte that caused illness
Epnon asked Mengeon Chandel if there were any of his dead mother's clothes she could have; refused
Jean Masson shared out garden with Epnon; her husband too ill to participate, so he did it himself in her presence; she was discontented
Wife of Jean Jacot le Masson wanted to put papers and holy water on fire during thunderstorm
Auparlier of Avould struck Epnon's second husband Claudon Mengel on head with pewter pot, leading to his death after 8 days illness
Bull worth 50 francs died after Epnon refused milk
Epnon was promised 100 francs compensation from legal case against Auparlier but never received it (200 francs supposed to go to children of previous marriage)

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; where Epnon lived and where most witnesses resided; Epnon had been resident more than 30 years
Seat of Prévôt who took informations preparatoires; Mengeon Chandel threatened to have Epnon taken there and tried as witch
Birthplace of Epnon; where her father Colas Martin was from
Where Epnon's first husband Mongeon Mathieu was from; a woman from Tantrux had accused Epnon and maintained accusation to her execution
Part of or near Sachemont; Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault and Mengeon Chandel de La Hault were from there
Where cunning woman lived who gave remedies to Claudon Colas; advised him on counter-magic including that wife should accept and eat food offered by suspected witch
Where Epnon's son was keeping horses towards Val de Moustier; where Jean Masson was working when he had relapse of headaches
In Allemagne; where Epnon's son (about 18 years old) was keeping horses
Where Jean Masson was told someone could identify the person who caused his illness (diviner)
How far Jean Masson got when going to see diviner in Burgundy before having remorse of conscience and turning back
Where Auparlier was from who allegedly struck Epnon's second husband Claudon Mengel on head with pewter pot
Where Vincent du Foire was from, the man Epnon later identified as having raped her 30 years before; said to be 'le thaurel ou voirel de la ville'
Where witness Mengel Forbain was from
Place where Epnon was accused of going to sabbat; literally refers to cauldron

historical_context.military_details: Unknown man who allegedly came into Epnon's house 30 years before was described as 'dressed in black and like a soldier'
weather_events: thunderstorm at night around St. Jean 2 years before trial when voice allegedly called Epnon to go out
thunderstorm mentioned when Epnon got up at night to do something with cauldron under bed
economic_hardship_indicators: Epnon described as very poor, owning only part of her house
Could hardly see, so had to beg rather than work
Did day labour or begged to support herself
Third husband had been ill for three years, emaciated and bedridden
Never received 100 francs compensation owed from legal case
Multiple witnesses described her coming to beg for food, milk, clothes
Pattern of refusals of charity preceding accusations of malefice
Epnon said she was alone with no defense or assistance to seek legal redress
religious_calendar_references: around St. Jean (June 24) 2 years before trial

prior_legal_disputes.description: Epnon's father-in-law brought a case against Auparlier of Avould, who had struck her second husband Claudon Mengel on the head with a pewter pot when they were in company at Avould. Husband died after 8 days illness. She was a party to the case.
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: She had been told that Auparlier was to pay compensation: 100 francs to her and 200 francs to children of Claudon Mengel by previous marriage, but she never received the 100 francs she was promised

legal_context.redress_outcome: Son-in-law Bastien Jean Chesne told her she should seek redress if she was 'femme de bien', otherwise one day they would apprehend her and put her on trial. She replied that she was alone and had no defense or assistance to do so. Witness 6 had often called her witch after being cured and was sure she had heard of this, but she had never taken any action.

change_de_nancy.modification_details: First approved torture (question ordinaire et extraordinaire) on 4 July 1615 same day it was requested. Then on 14 July 1615 when procureur general asked for further torture, Change de Nancy ruled she should be renvoyée jusqu'à rappel (released until recall) unless procureur general produced further evidence against her.

hearsay_chains.reporter: Michiel fils à Mengel de la Hault
hearsay_chains.content: Told of incident some 18 months earlier when daughter-in-law of accused had come to their house and reported how shortly before her mother-in-law had got up during night when it was thundering, to do something with a cauldron under bed. Next day husband of this woman (la Royenne) had accused his mother of having been to sabbat by the 'cramet'.

emotional_state_notes: Made sensible denials of crucial points
Often agreed to circumstantial detail while denying key accusations
Endured much pain under torture but was resolute
Left house hurriedly when she saw Michiel coming because she hated him on account of his accusations
Seemed to cry when Michiel made reference to sabbat incident

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Her son-in-law had told her of accusation about Claude Marie's bull in the morning, but she had later heard that it recovered during previous night (suggesting timeline didn't support witchcraft claim)
Denied whole story about giving dried cherries to Mongeatte; said it was impossible to stop people speaking ill of others

third_parties.name: daughter-in-law of Epnon (la Royenne)
third_parties.context: Shared house with Epnon; came to Michiel's house to report incident about mother-in-law getting up during thunderstorm to do something with cauldron under bed; next day her husband accused his mother of going to sabbat; later gave Michiel yeast, salt and joutte when Epnon left hurriedly

third_parties.name: husband of la Royenne (son of Epnon)
third_parties.context: Shared house with Epnon (they lived together); accused his mother of having been to sabbat by the 'cramet' after thunderstorm incident

third_parties.name: servants of Bastien Colas George
third_parties.context: Refused to give Epnon milk when she asked; she came and gone among animals

third_parties.name: servants of Claudon Grinel
third_parties.context: Told Epnon they could not give her something from cow without master's permission (though he often did make gifts when she came to house)

third_parties.name: servants of Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie
third_parties.context: Told witness that Epnon had passed and repassed in front of animals and now a bull was ill

third_parties.name: mother of Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie
third_parties.context: Was baking when Epnon came; Epnon did some baking herself; later sent with message to Epnon threatening arrest if she didn't take sickness off animal

third_parties.name: son-in-law of Elizabeth femme à Claude Marie
third_parties.context: Message about sick bull passed on through him to Epnon

third_parties.name: wife of Claudon Colas le viel homme
third_parties.context: Became unwell and lost her milk after giving birth; held feast for women where Epnon invited as neighbor but may have felt neglected; recovered after eating cherries brought by Epnon

third_parties.name: midwife of Claudon Colas's wife
third_parties.context: Recommended they seek remedy from woman of Souche

third_parties.name: cunning woman of Souche
third_parties.context: Gave Claudon Colas bread and something else he didn't know; said wife should eat a little for nine days; also said if they suspected someone of causing illness and she came to house before dinner offering something to eat, wife should have no fear about accepting and eating it because it would help her (counter-magic advice)

third_parties.name: daughter of Claudon Grinel
third_parties.context: Epnon asked her to make some toile; told she didn't have time at present

third_parties.name: wife of Jean Masson
third_parties.context: Had been giving Epnon milk from their goat, but perhaps not enough

third_parties.name: wife of Jean Jacot le Masson
third_parties.context: Lived with Epnon; Epnon said voice in the night would have been hers - wanted to put papers and holy water on fire on account of thunderstorm

third_parties.name: mother of Mengeon Chandel (deceased)
third_parties.context: After her death, Epnon asked if there were any of her clothes she could have; witness refused

third_parties.name: sisters of Mengeon Chandel
third_parties.context: Witness said they had far more claim to dead mother's clothes than any stranger did

third_parties.name: egiptiens (Egyptians/Gypsies)
third_parties.context: Had been in village and declared Claudatte's facial pains were caused by witchcraft

third_parties.name: woman of Tantrux
third_parties.context: Had recently accused Epnon; Epnon was taken to confrontation with her; woman maintained accusation up to her execution; this was mentioned to Epnon during torture interrogation

third_parties.name: Vincent du Foire of Bar-le-duc
third_parties.context: Epnon identified him as the man dressed in black like a soldier who came into her house 30 years before when her husband was away and had intercourse with her; initially described as rape, then said he promised money; said on the village to be 'le thaurel ou voirel de la ville' (the town bull or womanizer); his wife had told Epnon he ran after other women and kept two or three

third_parties.name: wife of Vincent du Foire
third_parties.context: Had told Epnon that her husband Vincent ran after other women and kept two or three

third_parties.name: Auparlier of Avould
third_parties.context: Second husband Claudon Mengel told Epnon that Auparlier, with whom he had been in company at Avould, had struck him on head with pewter pot; he died after 8 days illness; father-in-law brought case; Auparlier was to pay 100 francs to Epnon and 200 francs to children of previous marriage, but Epnon never received it

third_parties.name: father-in-law of Epnon (father of Claudon Mengel)
third_parties.context: Brought legal case against Auparlier for assault that killed his son Claudon Mengel

third_parties.name: children of Claudon Mengel by previous marriage
third_parties.context: Were supposed to receive 200 francs compensation from Auparlier in legal case

third_parties.name: Mongeatte
third_parties.context: Witness 11 claimed that about 3 years earlier, after childbirth, Epnon gave her dried cherries; she immediately became ill and had since remained 'chaitte ou etique' (wasted/consumptive), unable to work; Epnon denied whole story on confrontation

third_parties.name: son of Epnon (about 18 years old)
third_parties.context: One of two children by Jean Chesne; was alive and keeping horses towards Val de Moustier in Allemagne

third_parties.name: son of Claudatte femme de Colas Claudon Grainel (deceased)
third_parties.context: Had died about 2 years before; after customary dinner following burial, Epnon came to beg and was dissatisfied with plate of millet

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a highly unusual trial where the accused was released after resisting torture. Epnon maintained consistent denials throughout, agreeing to circumstantial details while denying key accusations. The Change de Nancy intervened twice: first approving torture, then blocking further torture and ordering her release unless more evidence was produced. Notable features: (1) Epnon was extremely poor (destitute) and relied on begging - could hardly see, owned only part of house; (2) Multiple witnesses used counter-magic, seeking items from her house to cure afflictions, suggesting belief she could both cause and cure; (3) She never confessed to a demonic pact despite torture; (4) Her story about being raped 30 years earlier by Vincent du Foire appears to be an attempt to explain away the devil seduction narrative without admitting to witchcraft - she insisted he was a normal man; (5) Strong evidence of economic tensions - she was repeatedly refused charity (milk, food, clothes) and was owed 100 francs from a prior legal case that she never received; (6) Witness 10 (Bastien Jean Chesne) was her son-in-law who lived with her and testified about thunderstorm incident and her reputation; (7) The cunning woman of Souche gave explicit counter-magic advice that relied on Epnon providing the cure herself - if suspected witch came offering food, accept and eat it because it would help; (8) Son of Epnon (by second husband) accused his own mother of going to sabbat by the 'cramet' (cauldron); (9) Document notes this was an 'unusually consistent case' in terms of her sensible denials; (10) C.M. Remy (author of Demonolatry) was the procureur general who requested torture.
